awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Development and Implementation of Computational Chemistry and Biology Courses with Research Integration
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Clark Atlanta University (CAU) seeks to increase the number of underrepresented minorities receiving undergraduate degrees in STEM through the targeted infusion of curriculum improvements and faculty engagement of undergraduate research. The development and implementation of two new courses in Computational Chemistry and Computational Biology through an interdisciplinary teaching and learning approach will be a model for other schools to enhance their curriculum in STEM education. CAU's undergraduate students, who will enroll in these courses, will work with supercomputers through the NSF supported Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE). These courses will be essential for underrepresented minority students at CAU to graduate with "Interdisciplinary Computational Chemistry and Biology Certification" and compete nationally with contemporary skill sets.

The overall goals of the project are to update the chemistry and biology curriculums and to educate undergraduate students in both computational chemistry and computational biology. To achieve these goals, the PIs plan to: 1) Develop, pilot-test, and implement two new undergraduate courses in the Departments of Chemistry and Biological Sciences and to educate twenty eight students with interdisciplinary computational skills; and 2) Enhance the academic cyberinfrastructure for computational chemistry and biology education integrated with research for undergraduate students. Achieving the goals will benefit CAU in moving to the next level to initiate a Computational Science "Minor" program for STEM undergraduates.

por.por_cntn:
Computational modeling is now regarded as an equal and essential element along with theory and experiment in the advancement of scientific knowledge and engineering practice. Currently, enormous opportunities are available in computational and data-enabled science. Demand for a workforce in this area is expected to increase significantly in coming years. It is important to educate the next generation of undergraduate students to face the challenges in computational and data science. At Clark Atlanta University (CAU), two (2) new courses "Introduction to Computational Chemistry and Molecular Modeling" and "Introduction to Computational Biology and Bioinformatics" were developed and implemented successfully. These two courses were approved by the University to include as a regular or elective course in the undergraduate curriculum for chemistry and biology majors. Both computational courses include laboratory components that provide hands-on experience on course topics using computers and scientific software.

This project provided opportunity for underrepresented undergraduate students in chemistry and biology to learn new techniques using computers to address the chemistry and biology issues or challenges, research training and mentoring by the faculty. Throughout the project period, more than one hundred students received training for using computers in chemistry or biology. Many of those students had opportunity to talk, listen and discuss with the external expert in the field of computational chemistry and computational biology when the experts visited CAU or delivered talk via zoom. Total of 26 undergraduate students were trained on research projects related to computational chemistry or computational biology/bioinformatics by the faculty and graduate student mentors. Those undergraduate students graduated with the skills and knowledge on computing to start their graduate school in performing research as partly or fully of computational nature. The computational chemistry and biology lab was created by setting up of eighteen workstation type computers with numerous software required for performing calculations relevant to the laboratories corresponding to the courses and undergraduate research projects. This high-tech computational lab strengthens the academic cyberinfrastructure at CAU for computational chemistry and biology undergraduate students.

Underrepresented undergraduate students in chemistry and biology departments were introduced to supercomputer at San Diego Supercomputer Center (SDSC) through SEAGrid Science Gateway. Many undergraduate students supported through this project had accessed supercomputers for performing calculations related to their laboratories or research projects. This NSF grant helped PI in co-organizing the workshop "Power Up Your Research with XSEDE" at Clark Atlanta University for faculty and students in 2019. This workshop provided training to participants to use high performance computing and introduction to python and XSEDE. The results of this project were disseminated in the form of oral or poster presentations at the American Chemical Society (ACS) National Meetings, other national/international conferences, webinars, published in peer-reviewed journals or book.
